image.altText: Israeli soldiers walk on grassy terrain.

items.synopsis: Israel says its infantry and tanks have carried out raids inside the Gaza Strip, its first announcement of a shift from an air war to ground operations to root out Hamas fighters a week after their deadly rampage in southern Israel.

title.children: Israeli military says troops have made their first ground raids into Gaza

image.altText: A woman walks past "vote yes" and "vote no" signs on a fence.

items.synopsis: The nation is bound for the ballot box today to cast their vote in a referendum that could shape the country for generations to come — but the path to this poll has been a rocky one.

title.children: A moment decades in the making: It's time for Australians to cast their votes on a new Voice

image.altText: A person in a crowd holds up a sign with the Aboriginal flag and the words "Voice to Parliament".

items.synopsis: A No vote — and how we got to one — will change the way we see ourselves, and send the most unloving of messages to Indigenous Australians, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: A prediction made 12 months ago is coming true — and it's sending a painful message

image.altText: A woman sobs as people stand against a sandstone wall at a funeral

items.synopsis: Israel is preparing to carry out a ground operation whose mission is to "destroy Hamas". But what then? What is the political reality and make-up of Gaza and what would it look like without Hamas, asks John Lyons.

title.children: 'Israel now will not stop': One week into war and a dangerous political reality has set in

image.altText: Socceroos' Craig Goodwin slides on his knees as teammates embrace him after a goal against France at the Qatar World Cup.

items.synopsis: Graham Arnold helped orchestrate the Socceroos' famous win over England in 2003. Can he do it again as Australia take on their old foes at Wembley? Follow live.

title.children: Socceroos face England in Wembley friendly

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Socceroos have made two changes to the team that started against Mexico in the last international window, with Ryan Strain earning his first ever start in place of of Nathaniel Atkinson and Craig Goodwin comes in for Riley McGree. England, meanwhile, are going for a bit of experimentation, swapping out all but one of their starting XI that defeated Scotland in September. 'bitta disrespect, maybe? Shades of 2003?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Line-ups!

children.content: The Socceroos have made two changes to the team that started against Mexico in the last international window, with
earning his first ever start in place of of
England, meanwhile, are going for a bit of experimentation, swapping out all but one of their starting XI that defeated Scotland in September.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As for England... well, they're pretty much a Fantasy Team at this point, aren't they? The Three Lions are using this game against the Aussies as a warm-up for their 2024 European Championship qualifier against Italy on Wednesday morning, so you can imagine manager Gareth Southgate will use today's game to test out a couple players and tactics. England have lost just twice inside 90 minutes at Wembley since 2018, and have some of the best players in the world within their ranks. Their front-line contains options like Bayern Munich forward Harry Kane, Manchester City pair Jack Grealish and Phil Foden, Manchester United forward Marcus Rashford, Arsenal winger Eddie Nketiah, and Tottenham creative weapon James Maddison. Their midfield boasts the likes of Declan Rice, Jordan Henderson, Kalvin Phillips, Conor Gallagher, and arguably the best young midfielder in the men's game right now, Real Madrid's Jude Bellingham. And their defensive unit contains names like Fikayo Tomori, Kyle Walker, Trent Alexander-Arnold, Lewis Dunk, Kieran Trippier, and Harry Maguire. So their squad might be a Panini sticker collection, but you know what England don't have? Aussie DNA. Who do you reckon will shine for England this morning, team? Who are you most excited to see?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What about those Poms, hey?

children.content: As for England... well, they're pretty much a Fantasy Team at this point, aren't they?

image.altText: Young people learning to weave.

items.synopsis: An Indigenous youth foundation condemns the reaction to a social media post about traditional weaving, saying it is a "real shame" online commenters are still "targeting young people" weeks after it was initially shared.

title.children: 'Relief' when referendum over, says founder of youth group following Facebook inundation

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and a black top looks into the camera.

items.synopsis: Despite the prominence of pro-Voice views in mainstream and social media, researchers tracking polling found the Yes campaign failed to sway voters.

title.children: No campaign outperforming Yes on social media, researchers say

image.altText: A woman smiles sitting down, she wears a dot painted blue and white top and glasses. She sits in shade cloth outshed.

items.synopsis: Aunty Cheryl Norris wants people to do their own research and vote from their hearts when they hit the booths.

title.children: The common message shared by Indigenous Yes and No voters in the Riverland

image.altText: Two volunteers wearing Yes and No campaign shirts stand next to each other with their faces cropped out.

items.synopsis: As an Aboriginal person, it feels impossible to digest the freight train of messages coming towards us each day. Most of it is about us, without us, writes Bridget Brennan.

title.children: The Voice debate has put the worst of Australia on display. Indigenous people deserve better

image.altText: A woman, a man and two young children look at the camera, surrounded by luggage and other people

items.synopsis: Tal Raymond, Dana Elhadad and their two young children were among the first Australians at Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion Airport for a Qantas repatriation flight on Friday, but not all of them got on board.

title.children: 'Hardest decision I've ever had to make': Aussie families torn apart at Tel Aviv airport

image.altText: A composite image of buildings with smoke behind them and a young girl speaking

items.synopsis: Palestinians say they are living in a "constant state of fear" as Gaza residents continue to struggle with no power and a dwindling food supply.

title.children: 'I doubt I will make it out alive': Gazans say they feel 'trapped in a cage' and 'waiting for death'

image.altText: Smoke is coming from Gaza following Israeli strikes.

items.synopsis: Israel tells civilians living in northern Gaza to head south, warning them the military will operate "significantly" in Gaza City in the coming days.

title.children: Israel Defense Forces warn over 1 million Gazans to relocate to the south — as it happened

image.altText: three men walk out of the kings cross police station after they were arrested for allegedly doing the nazi salute

items.synopsis: The men, aged 30, 31 and 40, are charged under new laws over the public display of Nazi flags and memorabilia banned across the state last year.

title.children: Three men charged over alleged Nazi salute outside Sydney Jewish Museum

image.altText: Vanessa Amorosi wears a black jacket and pants and brown top and holds a black bag as she walks behind a white car.

items.synopsis: Australian singer-songwriter Vanessa Amorosi has denied deliberately making a false statement to authorities, having a bad memory, and trying to win a legal case against her mother because she was short of money.

title.children: 'You guys are … disgusting': Emails between Vanessa Amorosi and her mother shown to court during civil trial

image.altText: The outside of the Toowoomba Court

items.synopsis: The identity of a high-profile man accused of rape in Toowoomba will remain a secret for now despite a court denying the man a non-publication order.

title.children: Identity of high-profile man accused of rape in Toowoomba will remain secret

image.altText: An animation of a spacecraft approaching an asteroid in space.

items.synopsis: The Psyche probe, folded inside the cargo bay of a SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket is due to reach the asteroid in August 2029.

title.children: NASA launches spacecraft to explore metal-rich asteroid believed to be worth $US10 quadrillion

image.altText: A portrait of a woman with long dark hair wearing a black top.

items.synopsis: Karinda Taylor runs an Aboriginal-led health service, where short election cycles make it difficult to secure long-term funding. She believes the Voice could help achieve generational change.

title.children: Karinda lost her father to a preventable disease when she was 14. Now she works to save lives in her community

image.altText: A map of Australia electorates divided between orange and purple.

items.synopsis: The rules that determine how the Voice referendum will be run were written more than 100 years ago.

title.children: In referendums, not all votes are created equal

image.altText: A woman with long brown hair in a white blazer standing in front of a Vote No poster.

items.synopsis: In a speech to the Conservative Political Action Conference, No campaigner Jacinta Nampijinpa Price said the gap in outcomes between Indigenous and non-Indigenous people was "more about place than race". Is that correct?

title.children: We fact checked Jacinta Nampijinpa Price on Indigenous disadvantage. Here's what we found

image.altText: Grass near Mount French burns to create a plume of smoke

items.synopsis: There are no longer any properties in danger after firefighters worked tirelessly to contain a "large, fast-moving" blaze near Mount French in Queensland's Scenic Rim.

title.children: Residents near Boonah advised to return with caution after fire threatened homes

image.altText: Smoke rises over the horizon from a grass fire burning 50 kilometres north of Inverell in the NSW.

items.synopsis: Residents at properties north-west of Ashford on Limestone Road were told on Friday if they were not prepared, then they should leave, as firefighters worked to defend about 10 properties.

title.children: Firefighters and aircraft work to defend properties from grassfire north of Inverell in NSW

items.synopsis: Police are investigating after shots were fired overnight. Do you recognise these offenders?

title.children: Watch the moment armed robbers threatened a Queensland security guard with a gun

image.altText: A-League Women's players Chloe Logarzo, Elise Kellond-Knight, Kyah Simon and Cortnee Vine in their team gear.

items.synopsis: If you're chasing World Cup fever, you don't have to go far to find it, with plenty of Matildas playing in the local league this year. Here's why it promises to be one of the best seasons yet.

title.children: Matildas stars hopeful World Cup legacy will spur on A-League Women's season

image.altText: A smiling woman on a beach.

items.synopsis: Micaela Guacci was lying on the beach when she noticed a distressed couple who had been pulled out to sea in a rip and put her life at risk to save them.

title.children: Nude swimmers in Noosa rescued by surfers and lifeguard visiting from Argentina

image.altText: A woman walking along a pathway

items.synopsis: Seven people have been diagnosed with colorectal cancer after Albury Wodonga health authorities conducted nearly 1,100 repeat colonoscopies for patients who received defective treatment from surgeon Dr Liu-Ming Schmidt.

title.children: Hospital apologises after seven people diagnosed with cancer following colonoscopy recall

items.synopsis: With cyclone season looming, concerns are growing about the increasing numbers of illegal fishing vessels roaming waters off the Kimberley.

title.children: Conservationist fires up after catching illegal fishers raiding Australian waters

image.altText: Part of a letter being held up

items.synopsis: It's been revealed authorities were warned about the worsening state of a 16-year now old fighting for his life in hospital two weeks before his suicide attempt in the youth wing of an adult prison.

title.children: WA government told of teenager's deteriorating state two weeks before he was found unresponsive in cell

image.altText: CCTV captured the scene before the Paddy Hannan statue was damaged.

items.synopsis: A woman is airlifted to Perth after being seriously injured in connection with the vandalism of a famous statue of a pioneering gold prospector in Kalgoorlie.

title.children: Woman suffers serious injuries as famous WA statue vandalised

image.altText: a senior police man standing outdoors and talking to the media

items.synopsis: Police will be able to search protesters and require identification ahead of a planned pro-Palestinian rally in Sydney's CBD.

title.children: Pro-Palestinian protestors say 'draconian' police powers won't stop Sydney rally

image.altText: Australasian College for Emergency Medicine NT chair Dr Stephen Gourley profile shot.

items.synopsis: Stephen Gourley says the Voice to Parliament is key for meaningful reconciliation that will improve the lives of Indigenous people who suffer with "diseases of poverty".

title.children: Voice vital to reconciliation, improved Indigenous health outcomes, says chief emergency doctor

image.altText: an aboriginal couple with a little baby

items.synopsis: A Northern Territory family with a one-month-old baby say they have spent weeks living in a public house overrun with sewage, despite repeated calls for help.

title.children: Remote NT family fear baby will fall ill due to 'disgusting' housing conditions

image.altText: A boxer clad in white smiles as a man puts his hand on his shoulder.

items.synopsis: Newly crowned WBO world champion Tim Tszyu isn't focused on "that guy" Jermell Charlo, but concerns have been raised over the referee ahead of his fight against Brian Mendoza on Sunday.

title.children: New world champion Tim Tszyu focused on 'what really matters'

image.altText: A Japanese male rugby union player with his arm around his coach as they celebrate a Rugby World Cup win in 2015.

items.synopsis: Eddie Jones is reportedly set to leave his role as Wallabies coach just nine months after taking the job, with the ABC confirming he is in the running for a return to Japan.

title.children: Wallabies coach Eddie Jones to interview for Japan job as reports swirl about early Australian exit

image.altText: Marie Piccone looking at mangoes

items.synopsis: It has taken decades of work and a number of setbacks, but three mango varieties are being commercially rolled out — and finally have names.

title.children: Yess! AhHa! Now! New names, new varieties of mango in supermarkets after years of development

image.altText: a black, blue and red scientific image of covid-19

items.synopsis: Here's a quick wrap of the COVID-19 news and case numbers from each Australian jurisdiction for the past week.

title.children: All the latest COVID-19 case numbers from around Australia
